title: The Split Tide
description: On the basalt parapets of the Tide-Gate Crown, where chain-bells speak the city’s pulse and eel-oil lanterns write wavering scripture upon wet stone, Vyraleth’s breath catches like a lung in storm. Convoys stack outside the mouth in a forest of masts and anxious prayer, their pilots peering through the Pale’s damp veil, waiting for a bell no one has yet dared to ring. The Brass Aerie’s banners quiver with unspent verbs while their dean threatens a stillness that could turn the harbor to glass, and House Veyron’s festival drums beat too neatly with the cadence of a coup. In the dry-dock’s shadow, Ratchet hardliners stroke chain and lever, imagining a city that turns to their hands, while Saltwardens count skiffs and excuses and the Order of Mnemos tallies oaths like coins. Iria Venn finds you where the gate’s teeth hum faintly to a drowned hymn, and she asks not for a guild’s victory but for the survival of hulls and crews and the hope-tangled rope that binds them. Two starshards—one in the Crown’s heart-cog and one asleep beneath the Basilica’s tides—must breathe in rhythm or the city will cough flood and famine into every ring. Tonight you must braid rivalries into a workable rope, coax a controlled gust instead of a killing calm, teach bells to sing a new convoy code, and unseat a bribed Saltwarden captain without breaking the line. If you succeed, Vyraleth will wake with salt on its lips and gratitude in its markets; if you fail, the leviathan’s ribs will remember how to cage a city that forgot how to breathe.
objectives: Broker a truce on the Gate Crown between Guild of Tidewrights, Tidebound Conclave, and Lantern Cartel using the joint writ.
Coordinate with Orrix Vant to allow a controlled gust, not a stillness, over the harbor.
Ring a new bell-code so Cartel pilots can time their entry with the shard’s safe window.
Expose the bribed Saltwarden captain tied to sabotage at Dry Dock Three and remove his skiffs from the chain of command without sparking mutiny.

dialogue.speaker: Iria Venn
dialogue.lines: I’ve flown blind with you in worse storms, Raithe, but this weather reeks of politics and that is the deadliest squall a pilot can taste. Give me a bell I can trust and a breath I can lean into, and I will thread thirty hulls through the city’s teeth without scraping enamel or pride. The Cartel will call me reckless if I move without sanction, but I’d sooner be reckless than watch crews rot at anchor while guilds argue over who owns the wind. I don’t come as a mouth for the Beacon Circle tonight; I come as a friend who knows your hands remember the ring-map scar and what it cost to earn it. If the shards sing together and the tide-gates learn this new song, we can make a window that even the Pale will respect; if they don’t, the harbor coughs, the Exchange panics, and the outer rings go hungry. I will trust your code and your courage, but you must promise me the gate will not close on my people mid-breath.

dialogue.speaker: Orrix Vant
dialogue.lines: You ask me to bend the wind, not break it, and that request is a balm I did not expect to hear on a night so fevered. Stillness is a blade, and though many fear it, more try to wield it; I will not turn the harbor to a mirror merely to win a negotiation. Give me your timings and the star-hum’s cadence, and I will write a gentle verb upon the gusts, enough for pilots to read their lines without stealing the harbor’s grammar. I have apprentices watching the cables and runes tuned to mercy, but I require the Tidewrights to hold their hinge steady and the Conclave to keep their knot-songs aligned, else my breath becomes a stutter. I remember Skyhook Cliffs and the way you hauled my boy from a silence that wanted him, and that memory weighs more than House Veyron’s tariffs in my scales. Bring me truth and a bell to rhyme with, and I will make the air kneel just enough to bow without surrender.

dialogue.speaker: Sel Corvane
dialogue.lines: Improvisation is a sin in the language of gates, Calder, and yet I dislike drowning more than I dislike sin. The Crown was not designed to sing with a shard beneath a basilica, but the heart-cog hums when their choirs do, and I am not deaf to necessity. Show me your new code and the Conclave’s joint writ, and I will narrow the throat to your measure, send the tide like a disciplined troop, and keep the hinge from jerking under a dozen competing hands. If your truce fractures or your pilots stray, I will shut the mouth without hesitation and bear the city’s curses until the flood forgets them. The Saltwardens think me timid and the Syndicate thinks me tyrant; they are both wrong and both impatient, and impatience drowns. Give me a reasoned plan with timings that respect the gear’s teeth, and I will stand where the waves break and hold.

dialogue.speaker: Raithe Calder
dialogue.lines: We are not choosing a victor tonight; we are choosing a dawn where everyone wakes. Iria, on the second long bell after the shard’s first hum, you bring your thirty in like a song returning to its chorus, and I will stand on the parapet so your pilots know the code is no trick. Orrix, when you hear that bell, write a mercy into the wind that guides, not governs, so even the most nervous helmsman can feel the lane as if the harbor itself had taken his wrist. Sel, you hold the hinge steady and let me carry the joint writ while the Conclave ties their vow-knot around the four of us; if anyone tries to pull a stunt, they answer to my blade and to the patience of thirty thousand souls. While the bells change their grammar, I will cut the bribed captain from the chain of command like rot from a rope without snapping the line that keeps his skiffs obedient. We will make the city breathe, together, and later we can argue the price; tonight, we buy survival with trust.

choices.title: Bind the Gate Truce by Knot and Memory
choices.text: You propose a formal knot-rite atop the Crown’s central parapet, witnessed by a Mnemos scribe and sealed with your Knot-Ring, so each faction is bound to the timings and the bell-code for one full tide. You invite Star-Prior Alion to intone a vow that acknowledges the shards’ dangerous sympathy while calling it holy work and not heresy, framing necessity as liturgy. Sel Corvane agrees to place two Saltwardens at each lever, not to guard against the Cartel but to guard his own nerves, and Iria Venn agrees to bring only pilots sworn to obey the code and stand down if the window closes. Orrix Vant, grumbling like a tame thunderhead, accepts a minor clause stating he will not still the harbor without a second bell, and in return he is allowed to tune the bell-striker for clarity. The crowd below reads the ceremony as law, not bargaining, and the rumor that the joint writ is inked in ember-ink spreads like a steadying charm. With the knot tied, you feel the ring tighten around your palm, a promise held like breath in the city’s chest.
choices.outcome: The truce holds through the critical hours, and with the Conclave’s blessing ringing more loudly than any guild’s pride, rivals behave as allies long enough for survival to feel ordinary. Pilots move in pairs, calling the new code as if it had always been written, and the Tidewrights’ crews discover they can trust the rhythm of the gate more easily than they can trust their own tempers. The Order of Mnemos records the event as an exemplar of emergency covenant, which quietly humiliates House Veyron’s festival planners and cools the Syndicate’s appetite for spectacle. In the outer rings, Wharfers applaud that their friends came home dry, and though they do not praise guilds, they mutter your name with a grudging warmth. The knot’s tug reminds you that if anyone breaks the agreement before ebb, you will feel the failure like a bruise, but the bruise never comes. By dawn, no coffins are being built, and the city’s first gossip is about the bell’s new poetry rather than its toll.

choices.title: Whisper to the Windwright
choices.text: You climb to the Aerie’s gantry with your windglass visor, reading the shimmer in the air where Orrix’s apprentices have already begun to spell a breeze, and you tell him the harbor needs a nudge, not a command. You describe lanes as if they were ropes for greenhands to seize, with slack enough to forgive, and you mark the timings with tide-marks etched on your falchion’s spine so the gust can be trained to those beats. Orrix listens, then tunes his cables to a low, kind hum that will carry in the ribs of hulls rather than rattle their masts, and he warns you that any sudden shift in the Tidewrights’ flow will turn kindness into confusion. You accept the warning, promise to hold Sel to steadiness, and ask for a signal—a small banner woven with a wind-rune—that pilots can read from the bell-tower when the breath is true. The Aerie’s banners unfurl like careful prayers, and even the hooklings on the cliffs fall silent to hear which way words will travel tonight. You leave the gantry with a cut on your palm from a cable that sang too sharply, a reminder that gentleness has an edge.
choices.outcome: The controlled gust moves like a teacher’s hand, laying guidance on the shoulders of ships without shoving, and pilots find themselves finishing turns they thought impossible. The harbor keeps its grammar, and the Aerie earns goodwill that tastes different from rent—sweeter, if more fragile—while the Lantern Cartel’s dispatchers whisper that Orrix’s cable-song finally learned humility. Sel’s crews, feeling the air’s honesty, resist the urge to ‘help’ with extra flow, and their restraint becomes the evening’s quiet heroism. A few banners tear as the gusts settle into their work, but the Collegium calls that tuition and not loss, and Orrix privately admits he prefers the craft of small mercies to the theater of great calms. House Veyron’s rumor mill spins futilely, unable to blame an invisible wind for failing to create a riot, and the Free Wharfers note that the air seemed to favor little boats as fairly as great ones. By midnight, gulls sleep on the boom-lines and not a single skiff has capsized from surprise.

choices.title: Ring the New Code from the Crown
choices.text: You take the bell-key ring in your salt-burned hand and climb to the striker’s perch, where the brass tongue remembers riots and weddings alike, and you teach it a new grammar. The code you crafted marries the Basilica’s drowned hymn with the Gate Crown’s chain-song, five strokes that rise, two that fall, and a patient pause where the shards may breathe together without complaint. Iria waits with her convoy at the mouth, sighting the bell tower through Pale and prayer, and Orrix counts the beats with you by gesture, each of you trusting the other’s clock more than your own. Sel watches the gate’s teeth with a lover’s fear and a surgeon’s skill, and when you look down you see not a crowd but a city listening the way a drowning man listens for rope. The first strike shivers the cog, the second calms it, the third is a promise, the fourth a warning, and the fifth a door; the two falling strokes are forgiveness if anyone falters. You finish with the long-held breath the city didn’t know it had, and the bell’s echo travels the rings like a rumor of mercy made metal.
choices.outcome: Pilots take the mouth of the river with a confidence that looks like fate and is, in fact, the product of timing and trust, and the Lantern Cartel records a new standard for fog passage. The shard in the Crown hums in sympathy with the Basilica’s hidden twin, not in rebellion, and the gate’s gears settle into a rhythm so clean that even old Saltwardens wipe at their eyes and pretend it’s the spray. The bell-code’s pause becomes a sacred second in the harbor’s vocabulary, a place where crews bow their heads and check their lines and remember to breathe. A few Free Wharfers, listening from the Bone Bridge, claim the rib’s shadows fell in the same rhythm, and that omen will be told for years to steady greenhands. The Lantern Cartel presents you with the bell-key ring engraved with the convoy code as if handing you a harmless relic, but you feel the weight of it like duty. In the Exchange, neutral merchants quietly agree that whatever else you are, you can be trusted to make a city-sized thing exhale without breaking.

choices.title: Pull the Rotten Captain Without Breaking the Line
choices.text: You choose a quiet removal instead of a roaring spectacle, gathering the ledger-leaf that ties a Saltwarden captain to Dry Dock Three’s sabotage and pairing it with the Conclave’s vow of immediate suspension for oath-tainted hands. You approach the captain on the Crown’s shadowed stair with two witnesses—one Mnemos clerk whose eyes glow faintly at truth, and one veteran wharf matron whose silence carries more weight than a squad of skiffs—and you speak softly so his crew only hears the dignity in your tone. You tell him the choice: stand aside for one tide and submit to inquiry, or be named publicly on the bell and watched by a city that has no patience left for treachery, and you let him see the knot-ring on your finger and the pity in your face. He calculates the odds, senses that mutiny will drown his own men faster than any wave, and hands you his chain of office like a man laying down a knife he loves too much. You send his skiffs on ‘maintenance rotation’ under Sel’s authority, swapping their oars quietly with Orrix’s spare kite-lines so they cannot surge in a moment of pride, and you give the captain a slow path to redemption he may or may not deserve. The only sound is a bell breath between strikes, as if the city looks away to spare him a moment of shame.
choices.outcome: The removal lands like rain instead of hail, soaking in without bruising, and the captain’s crews accept the fiction of maintenance because it protects their wages and their dignity. The Ratchet Syndicate’s ears perk at the sudden absence of a hostile skiff wing and choose not to test the levers tonight, uncertain which nets are waiting. The Saltwardens Consortium grumbles in private but cannot contradict a joint writ that includes Conclave authority and Mnemos record, and by morning they will pretend they ordered the suspension first. Your discretion earns you a nod from Sel and a long, considering gaze from Iria that says you chose mercy where blood might have pleased the crowd. In taverns, the story becomes a lesson in how to cut bad rope without losing the cargo, and even the Free Wharfers admit that fewer bruises were a victory. By dawn, the only skiffs moving are the ones that should, and the chain of command has fewer corrupt links clanking in it.

rewards.description: Gate Crown bell-key ring with the new convoy code engraved, recognized by pilots and Saltwarden signalers alike.
100 coin in stamped harbor-guild marks paid upon successful convoy threading and safe passage at ebb.
Joint commendation from the Lantern Cartel and Brass Aerie Collegium: priority beaconing for one future evacuation or relief mission.
Public reputation boon: 'Broker of the Breath' and discounts with neutral merchants at the Brine Exchange.
